editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: Hide Parke a comedie, as it vvas presented by her Majesties Servants, at the private house in Drury Lane. Written by Iames Shirly.
titleStmt.author: Shirley, James, 1596-1666.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke,

note.p: Reproduction of the original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.p: Hide park a comedy, as it was presented by her majesty's servants, at the private house in Drury lane.
London, printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. 1637.

div.head: To the right honourable, Henry Earl of Holland, knight of the most noble order of the garter, one of his majesty's most honourable privy council, chancellor of the university of Cambridge, etc.
div.p: This comedy in the title, is a part of your lordship's command, which heretofore graced, and made happy by your smile, when it was presented, after a long silence, upon first opening of the park, is come abroad to kiss your lordship's hand. The applause it once received in the action, is not considerable with that honour, your lordship may give it in your acceptance; that was too large, and might with some narrow and stoical judgement render it suspected: but this, depending upon your censure, (To me above many theatres) is able to impart a merit to the poem, and prescribe opinion. If your lordship, retired from business into a calm, and at truce with those high affairs, wherein your counsel and spirit is fortunately active, vouchsafe to peruse these unworthy papers. You not only give a life to the otherwise languishing numbers, but quicken, and exalt the genius of the author, whose heart pointeth at no greater ambition, than to be known

closer.signed: To your name and honour the most humbly devoted James Shirley.

div.head: The first act.

sp.speaker: Tryer,
sp.l: And how and how?

sp.speaker: Lacy,
sp.l: The cause depends.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: No mistress.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yes, but no wife.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: For now she is a widow.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But I resolve —

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: What does she say to thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: She says, I know not what she says, but I must take another course, and yet she is —

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: A creature of much sweetness, if all tongues
Be just in her report, and yet 'tis strange
Having seven years expected, and so much
Remonstrance of her husband's loss at sea,
She should continue thus.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What if she should
Renew the bond of her devotion
For seven years more.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You will have time enough,
To pay in your affection.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'd make,
A voyage to Cassandra's temple first,
and marry a deformed maid, yet I must
Confess she gives me a fair respect.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Has she,
A hope her husband may be living yet?
I cannot tell; she may have a conceit,
Some dolphin has preserved him in the storm,
Or that he may be tenant to some whale;
Within whose belly he may practise Lent,
And feed on fish, till he be vomited
Upon some coast, or having scaped the seas,
And bills of exchange failing, he might purpose
To foot it o'er the Alps in his return,
And by mischance is fallen among the mice,
With whom perhaps he battens upon sleep,
Beneath the snow.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: This were a vagary.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know not what to think, or is she not the worse for the coy lady that lives with her.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Her kinswoman?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Such a malicious piece,
(I mean to love) 'tis pity any place
But a cold nunnery should be troubled with her;
If all maids were but her disciples, we
Should have no generation, and the world
For want of children in few years undone by't:
Here's one can tell you more, is not that Jarvis
The widow's servant.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Whether in such haste man?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I am commanded sir to fetch a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: To thy mistress? To give her a heat this morning.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I ha' spied him; with your pardon — the servant goes to Laey

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Good morrow master venture.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Frank Tryer.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You look jocund and high,
Venus has been propitious,
I dreamt last night thou wert a bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Such a thing may be, the wind blows now
From a more happy coast,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I must leave you, I am sent for,

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: To thy mistress?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Without more ceremony, gentlemen my service farewell.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I'll tell thee, I have a mistress.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I believe it

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: And yet I have her not.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: But you have hope.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Or rather certainty.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Why, I hear she is
A very tyrant over men.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Worse, worse,
The needle of a dial never had
So many waverings, but she is touched,
And she points only this way now, true North;
I am her pole.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: And she your ursa minor,

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I laugh to think how other of her rivals
Will look when I enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You're not yet contracted?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: No she changed
Some amorous tokens, do you see this diamond?
A toy she gave me.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: 'Cause she saw you a spark.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Her flame of love is here, and in exchange
She took a chain of pearl.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You'll see it hanged.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: These to the wise are arguments of love,
And mutual promises.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Your lordship's welcome to town,
I am blessed to see your honour in good health.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Prithee visit my lodgings.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I shall presume to tender my humble service.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: A sprig of the nobility,
that has a spirit equal to his fortunes,
A gentleman that loves clean nappery.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I guess your meaning.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: A lady of pleasure, 'tis no shame for men
Of his high birth to love a wench his honour
May privilege more sins, next to a woman
He loves a running horse, setting aside these recreations,
He has a noble nature, valiant, bountiful.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I was of his humour till I fell in love,
I mean for wenching, you may guess a little,
By my legs, but I'll now be very honest,
And when I am married —

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Then you are confident
To carry away your mistress from 'em all.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: From Jove himself though he should practise all
His shapes to court her, 'tis impossible
She should put any trick upon me, I
Have won her very soul.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Her body must
Needs be your own then.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I have a brace of rivals
Would they were here that I might jeer 'em,
And see how opportunely one is come,
I'll make you a little sport.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I ha' been melancholy.
You will, express a favour in't.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: M. venture, the first man in my wish
What gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: A friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: I am his servant, look yet, we are friends ▪
An't shall appear, however things succeed
That I have loved you, and you cannot take
My council in ill part.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What's the business?

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: For my part, I have
used no enchantment, philtre, no devices
That are unlawful, to direct the stream
Of her affection, it flows naturally.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: How's this? prithee observe.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I do and shall laugh presently.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: For your anger
I wear a sword, though I have no desire
It should be guilty of defacing any
Part of your body, yet upon a just
And noble provocation, wherein
My mistress love, and honour is engaged,
I dare draw blood.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: A mistress love and honour? this is pretty.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: I know you cannot
But understand me, yet I say I love you,
And with a generous breast, and in the confidence
You will take it kindly, I return to that
I promised you, good council, come leave off
The prosecution.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Of what I prithee?

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: There will be less affront then to expect
Till the last minute, and behold the victory
Another's, you may guess, why I declare this?
I am studious to preserve an honest friendship.
For though it be my glory, to be adorned
With trophies of her vanquished love.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Whose love?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: This sounds as if he jeered you

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Mushroom!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: What d'ye mean gentlemen? friends and fall out
About good council.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I'll put up a gain
Now I think better on't:

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: 'Tis done discreetly,
Cover the nakedness of your tool I pray.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Why look you sir. If you bestow this council
Out of your love, I thank you; yet there is
No great necessity, why you should be at
The cost of so much breath, thing's well considered.
A lady's love is mortal, I know that,
And if a thousand men should love a woman
The dice must carry her, but one of all
Can wear the garland.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Now you come to him.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: For my own part, I loved the lady well,
But you must pardon me, if I demonstrate
There's no such thing as you pretend, and therefore
In quittance of your loving, honest council,
I would not have you build an airy castle,
Her stars have pointed her another way,
This instrument will take her height.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: And you may guess what cause you have to triumph,
I would not tell you this, but that I love you,
And hope you will not run yourself into
The cure of bedlam, he that wears this favour
Hath sense to apprehend.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: That diamond.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Observe it perfectly, there are no trophies
Of vanquished love, I take it, coming towards you,
It will be less affront, than to expect
Till the last minute, and behold the victory
Another's.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: That ring I gave her.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: This was his gift to her, ha, ha, ha!
Have patience spleen, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: The scene is changed!

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: She wonot use me thus, she did receive it
With all the circumstance of love.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I pity him, my eyes run o'er, dost hear,
I cannot choose but laugh, and yet I pity thee.
She has a jeering wit, and I shall love her
More heartily for this. What dost think?
Poor gentleman how he has fooled himself.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: I'll to her again.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Nay, be not passionate!
A faith thou wert too confident, I knew
It could not hold, dost think I'd say so much else?
I can tell thee more, but lose her memory.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Were it more rich
sp.stage: He shows a chain of pearl.
sp.l: Then that which Cleopatra gave to Anthony,
With scorn I would return it.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: She give you this chain?

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: She shall be hanged in chains, ere I will keep it.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Stay, stay, let my eye
Examine that — this chain —

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Who would trust woman after this?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: The very same
She took of me, when I received this diamond.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Ha ha! you do but jest, she wonot fool
You o'this fashion, look a little better, one may be like another.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: 'Tis the same.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Ha, ha, I would it were, that we might laugh
At one another, by this hand I will
Forgive her, prithee tell me — ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You will carry her
From Jove himself, though he should practise all
His shapes to court her.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: By this pearl, oh rogue!
How I do love her fort, be not dejected;
A lady's love is mortal, one of all
Must wear the garland, do not fool yourself
Beyond the cure of bedlam.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: She has fitted you
With a pair of fool's coats, as handsomely
As any tailor, that had taken measure,

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Nay lay your heads together
How to revenge it, and so gentlemen I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: She has abused us.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Let us take his council,
We can be but what we are.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: A pair of credulous fools.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: This other fellow Fairefeild has prevailed.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Which if he have —

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I think we were best let him alone.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: D'ye hear? We'll to her again, you'll
Be ruled by me, and tell her what we think on her.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: She may come to herself, and be ashamed on't.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: If she would affect one of us, for my part
I am indifferent.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: So say I too, but to give us both the canvas
Let's walk, and think how to behave ourselves.

div.stage: Enter mistress Bonavent, and mistress Caroll.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What d'ye mean to do with him?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Thou art
To much a tyrant, the seven years are past,
That did oblige me to expect my husband
Engaged to sea, and though within those limits
Frequent intelligence hath reported him
Lost, both to me, and his own life, I have
Been careful of my vow; and were there hope
Yet to embrace him, I would think another
Seven years no penance, but I should thus
Be held a cruel woman, in his certain
Loss, to despise the love of all mankind.
And therefore I resolve, upon so large
A trial of his constancy, at last
To give him the reward of his respects.
To me and —

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Marry him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You have apprehended!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: No marvel if men rail upon you then,
and doubt whether a widow may be saved,
We maids are thought the worse on, for your easiness,
How are poor women overseen? We must
Cast a way ourselves upon a whining lover
In charity, I hope my cousins ghost
Will meet, as you go to church, or if
You scape it then, upon the wedding night —

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: When you are both a-bed and candles out.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nay put not out the candles.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: May they burn blue then, at his second kiss
And fright him from — well I could say something
But take your course — he's come already.
Put him off, but another twelvemonth , so, so,
O love into what foolish labyrinths
Dost thou lead us! I would all women were
But of my mind, we would have a new world
Quickly, I will go study poetry,
A purpose, to write verses in the praise
Of th' Amazonian ladies, in whom only
Appear true valour (For the instruction
Of all posterity) to beat their husbands.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How you endear your servant.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I will not
Be guilty of more stay.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You're come in time sir, to redeem me.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Why lady.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You will be as comfortable as strong waters,
There's a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: So uncivil to affront you?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I had no patience to hear him longer;
Take his offence before you question him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: And be most happy if by any service
You teach me to deserve your fair opinion.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: It is not civil to eavesdrop him, but
I'm sure he talks on't now.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Of love, is any thing more ridiculous?
You know I never cherish that condition,
In you 'tis the most harsh unpleasing discord,
But I hope you will be instructed better
Knowing how much my fancy goes against it,
Talk not of that and welcome.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: You retain
I see your unkind temper, will no thought
Soften your heart, disdain agrees but ill
With so much beauty; if you would persuade,
Me not to love you, strive to be less fair;
Undo that face, and so become a rebel,
To heaven and nature.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You do love my face then!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: As heavenly prologue to your mind, I do not
Dote like Pygmalion on the colours!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: No you cannot, his was a painted mistress,
Or if it be the mind you so pretend
To affect, you increase my wonder of your folly,
For I have told you that so often.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: My mind so opposite to all your courtship,
That I had rather hear the tedious tales
Of Hollinghead, than any thing that trenches
On love, if you come fraught with any,
Cupid's devices, keep 'em for his whirligigs,
Or land the next edition of his messenger,
Or post with a mad packet, I shall but
Laugh at them, and pity you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That pity —

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Do not mistake me, it shall be a very
Miserable pity without love!
Were I a man, and had but half that handsomeness ,
(For though I have not love, I hate detraction,)
Ere I would put my invention to the sweat
Of compliment, to court my mistress hand
And call her smile blessing beyond a sun beam,
entreat to wait upon her, give her rings
With wanton, or most lamentable poesies,
I would turn thrasher.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: This is a new doctrine,
From women.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: 'I will concern your peace, to have some faith in't.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: You would not be neglected.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You neglect
Yourselves, the nobleness of your birth and nature
By servile flattery of this jigging,
And that coy mistress, keep your privilege
Your masculine property.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Is there
So great a happiness in nature!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: There's one
Just a your mind; can there be such happiness
In nature, fie upon't if it were possible,
That ever I should be so mad to love,
To which I thank my stars I am not inclined,
I should not hold such servants worth my garters,
Though they would put me in security
To hang themselves, and ease me of their visits.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You're a strange gentlewoman! why, look you lady?
I am not so enchanted with your virtues
But I do know myself, and at what distance
To look upon such mistresses,
I can be scurvily conditioned, you are —

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: As thou dost hope for any good, rail now
But a little.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I could provoke you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: To laugh, but not to lie down, why! prithee do!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Go you're a foolish creature, and not worth
My services.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: A loud that they may hear,
The more the merrier, I'll take't as kindly
As if thou hadst given me the exchange, what all this cloud
Without a shower?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: You're most ingrateful!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Good, abominable peevish, and a wench
That would be beaten, beaten black and blue.
And then perhaps she may have colour for't,
Come, come, you cannot scold with confidence
Nor with grace, you should look big and swear
You are no gamester, practise dice
And cards a little better, you will get
Many confusions and fine curses by't.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Is not she mad?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: To show I have my reason
I'll give you some good council; and be plain wi'ye
None that have eyes, will follow the direction
Of a blind guide, and what d'ye thing of Cupid?
Women are either fools, or very wise,
Take that from me, the foolish women are
Not worth your love, and if a woman know
How to be wise, she wonot care for you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Do you give all this council without a fee?
Come, be less wild! I know you cannot be
So hard of soul.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Prithee let my body alone!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Why are you thus peremptory? had
Your mother been so cruel to mankind,
This heresy to love, with you had been unborn.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: My mother was no maid.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: How lady?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: She was married long ere I was born, I take it,
Which I shall never be, that rules infallible,
I would not have you fooled it'h expectation,
A favour all my suitors cannot boast of,
Go home and say your prayers, I wonot look
For thanks till seven year hence.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I know not what
To say, yes I will home and think a satire,
Was man jeered thus for his good will?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: The licence will be soon dispatched.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.l: Leave that
To my care lady, and let him presume,
Whom you intend to bless with such a gift,
Seal on your lips the assurance of his heart,
I have more wings than Mercury, expect
Your servant in three minutes.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Take more time!
You'll over heat yourself and catch a surfeit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My nimble lady I ha' business, we
Will have a dialogue another time.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You do intend to marry him then.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I have promised
To be his wife, and for his more security
This morning.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: How? this morning?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: What should one
That has resolved lose time? I do not love
Much ceremony, suits in love, should not
Like suits in law, be racked from term to term.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You will join issue presently, without your council,
You may be o'er thrown; take heed, I have known wives
That have been o'er thrown in their own case, and after
Non suited too, that's twice to be undone,
But take your course, some widow's have been mortified.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: And maids do now and then meet with their match.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: What is in your condition makes you weary?
You're sick of plenty and command, you have
Too too much liberty, too many servants,
Your jewels are your own, and you would see
How they will show upon your husband's wagtail,
You have a coach now, and a Christian livery
To wait on you to church, and are not catechised
When you come home, you have a waiting-woman,
A monkey, squirrel, and a brace of islands
Which may be thought superfluous in your family
When husbands come to rule. A pretty wardrobe
A tailor of your own, a doctor too
that knows your body, and can make you sick
It'h spring, or fall, or when you have a mind to't
Without control, you have the benefit
Of talking loud and idle at your table
May sing a wanton ditty, and not be chid,
Dance and go late to bed, say your own prayers,
Or go to heaven by your chaplain.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Very fine.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: And will you lose all this? For I Sisley, take thee John,
To be my husband; keep him still to be your servant,
Imitate me, a hundred suitors cannot
Be half the trouble of one husband. I
Dispose my frowns, and favours like a Princess
Deject, advance, undo, create again
It keeps the subjects in obedience,
And teaches 'em to look at me with distance.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But you encourage some.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: 'Tis when I ha' nothing else to do for sport,
As for example.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But I am not now in tune to hear 'em, prithee
Let's withdraw.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Nay, nay, lady we must follow ye.

div.head: The second act.

sp.speaker: M. Bon.
sp.l: Music and revels? they are very merry.
By your favour sir.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You're welcome.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Pray is this a dancing school.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: No dancing school.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And yet some voices sound like women.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Will't please you
To taste a cup of wine, 'tis this day free
As at a coronation; you seem
A gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Prithee who dwells here?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The house this morning was a widow's sir!
But now her husbands, without circumstance
She is married.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Prithee her name.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Her name was mistress Bonavent.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How long since her husband died.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis two years since she had intelligence
He was cast away, at his departure he
Engaged her to a seven years expectation
Which full expired this morning she became
A bride.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What's the gentleman she has married.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: A man of pretty fortune, that has been
Her servant many years.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How d'ye mean wantonly, or does he serve for wages.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Neither, I mean a suitor.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Cry 'Mercy, may I be acquainted with his name.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: And his person too, if you have a mind to't
Master Lacy, I'll bring you to him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Mr. Lacy, may be 'tis he, would thou couldst help me to
A sight of this gentleman, I ha' business with
One of his name, and cannot meet with him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Please you walk in.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I would not be intruder
In such a day, if I might only see him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Follow me and I'll do you that favour.

div.stage: Enter Lacy, and his bride, rider, and carell, Venture, dancing: Bon. a loof.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Who's that peeps?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Peeps! who's that? faith you shall dance.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Good sir you must excuse me, I am a stranger.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your tongue does walk our language, and your feet
Shall do as we do, take away his cloak
And sword, by this hand you shall dance monsieure no pardonne moye!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Well said master bridegroom, the gentleman
May perhaps want exercise.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: He will not take it well.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: The bridegroom's merry!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Take me no takes, come choose your firk
For dance you shall.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I cannot, you'll not compel me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I ha' sworn.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: 'Tis an affront as I am a gentleman,
I know not how to foot your chamber jigs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No remedy, here's a lady longs for one vagary
Fill a bowl of sack, and then to the canaries.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: You are circled with your friends, and do not well
To use this privilege to a gentleman's
Dishonour.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You shall shake your heels.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I shall, ladies 'tis this gentleman's desire
That I should make you mirth, I cannot dance
I tell you that afore.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: He seems to be a gentleman and a soldier.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Good Mars be not so sullen, you'll do more
With Venus privately.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Because this gentleman is engaged I'll try.
Will you excuse me yet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Play excuse me, yes any thing you'll call for.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: This motion every morning will be wholesome
And beneficial to your body sir.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Your pretty lump requires it.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Where's my sword, sir I have been your hobby horse.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You danced something like one.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Jeer on my whimsy lady.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Pray impute it
No trespass studied to affront you sir,
But to the merry passion of a bridegroom.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Prithee stay, we'll to hide park together!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: There you meet with morris-dancers, for
You lady I wish you more joy, so farewell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Comes, ha tother whirl, lustily boys!

div.stage: Enter master Fairefeild and his sister Julietta.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You are resolved then.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I have no other care left,
And if I do't not quickly my affection
May be too far spent, and all physic will
Be cast away.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You will show a manly fortitude.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: When saw you master Tryer?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not since yesterday!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Are not his visits frequent?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He does see me sometimes!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Come! I know thou lovest him! and he will
Deserve it, he's a pretty gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: It was your character, that first commended
Him to my thoughts!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: If he be slow to answer it
He loses me again, his mind more than
His fortune gained me to his praise, but I
Trifle my precious time.
Farewell! all my good wishes stay with thee.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: And mine attend you! Master Tryer.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I come to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: And take your leave.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Only to kiss't again!

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You begin to be a stranger! in two mornings
Not one visit, where you profess affection.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I should be surfeited with happiness
If I should dwell here.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Surfeits in the spring
Are dangerous, and yet I never heard,
A lover would absent him from his mistress
Through fear to be more happy, but I allow
That for a compliment, and dispute not with you
A reason of your actions : you're now welcome
And though you should be guilty of neglect,
My love would overcome any suspicion.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You are all goodness
With me prithee admit him!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Sir, my lord saw you enter, and desires
To speak with you!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: His lordship shall command, where is he?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Below sir!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Say, I instantly wait on him?
Shall I presume upon your favour lady?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: In what!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: That I may entreat him hither, you will honour me
To bid him welcome, he is a gentleman
To whom I owe all services, and in
Himself is worthy of your entertainment.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: If he be yours command me!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: My lord! excuse

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Nay I prevent your trouble — lady I am
Your humble servant, pardon my intrusion
I hano business, only I saw you enter.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Your lordship honours me.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What gentlewoman's this.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Why —

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: A lady of pleasure, I like her eye, it has
A pretty twirl, what-will she bid one welcome.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Be confident my lord, sweet lady pray
Assure his lordship he is welcome,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I want words.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: O sweet lady your lip in silence
Speaks the best language.

sp.speaker: Iu
sp.l: Your lordship's welcome to this humble roof!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I am confirmed.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: If your knew lady, what
Perfection of honour dwells in him,
You would be studious with all ceremony
To entertain him! beside, to me
His lordship's goodness hath so flowed, you cannot
Study, what will oblige more than in his welcome!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Come, you compliment.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Though I want both ability and language,
My wishes shall be zealous to express me
Your humble servant:

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Come, that humble was
But compliment in you too.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I wood not
Be guilty of dissembling with your lordship,
I know words have more proportion
With my distance to your birth and fortune,
Then humble servant.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I do not love these distances.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You would have her be more humble, this will try her,
If she resist his siege, she is a brave one,
I know he'll put her to't, he that doth love
Wisely, will see the trial of his mistress,
And what I want in impudence myself,
Another may supply for my advantage,
I'll frame excuse!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Frank thou art melancholy!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: My lord I now reflected on a business,
Concerns me equal with my fortune, and
It is the more unhappy that I must,
So rudely take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What? not so soon.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Your honour's pardon.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Are you sir in earnest!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Love will instruct you to interpret fairly,
They are affairs that cannot be dispensed with,
I leave this noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He's a stranger,
You wonot use me well, and show no care
Of me, nor of my honour, I pray stay!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Thou hast virtue to secure all, I am confident,
Temptations will shake thy innocence,
No more than waves, that climb a rock, which soon
Betray their weakness, and discover thee,
More clear and more impregnable
How is this?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Farewell, I will not sin against your honour's clemency
To doubt your pardon.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Well and there be no remedy I shall see you
Anon ith' park, the match holds, I am not willing
To leave you alone lady.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I have a servant.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You have many, in their number pray write me,
I shall be very dutiful.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: O my lord!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: And when I have done a fault I shall be instructed,
But with a smile to mend it.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Done what fault?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Faith none at all, if you but think so.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I think your lordship would not willingly
Offend a woman.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I would never hurt 'em,
'Thas been my study still to please those women,
That fell within my conversation.
I am very tender hearted to a lady,
I can deny 'em nothing.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The whole sex is bound to you.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: If they well considered things,
And what a stickler I am in their cause,
The common cause, but most especially
How zealous I am in a virgin's honour,
As all true knights should be, no woman could
Deny me hospitality, and let down,
When I desire access, the rude portcullis,
I have a natural sympathy with fair ones,
As they do, I do! there's no handsome woman
Complains, that she has lost her maidenhead;
But I wish mine had been lost with it.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Your lordship's merry!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: 'Tis because you look pleasant,
A very handsome lodging, is there any
Accommodations that way.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: There's a garden,
Wilt please your lordship taste the air on't.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I meant other conveniency, but if
You please I'll wait upon you thither.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: You and I had better stay, and in their absence
Exercise one another.

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: How mean you page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I'll teach you away that we may follow 'em,
And not remove from hence.

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: How prithee?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Shall I beg your lip?

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: I cannot spare it.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I'll give you both mine.

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: What means the child?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Because I have no upper lip, d'ye scorn me?
I ha' kissed ladies before now, and have
Been sent for to their chambers.

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: You, sent for!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Yes, and been trusted with their closets too!
We are such pretty things, we can play at
All hid under a farthingale; how long
Have you been a waiting creature?

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: Not a month yet.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Nay then I cannot blame your ignorance, you have perhaps your maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: O lamentable! away with it for shame,
Chaffer it with the coachman, for the credit
Of your profession, do not keep it long,
'Tis fineable in court.

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: Good master page,
How long have you been skilled in those affairs?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Ere since I was in breeches, and you'll find
Your honesty so troublesome.

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: How so.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: When you have trucked away your maidenhead,
You have excuse lawful, to put off gamesters,
For you may swear, and give 'em satisfaction,
You have not what they looked for, beside the benefit
Of being impudent as occasion serves,
a thing much in request, with waiting creatures,
We pages can instruct you in that quality,
So you be tractable.

sp.speaker: Waiting-woman
sp.l: The boy is wild.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: And you will lead me a chase, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Why, did you ever think, I could affect
Of all men living such a thing as you are.
What hope, or what encouragement did I give you
Because I took your diamond, must you presently
Bound like a stoned horse.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: She's a very colt!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: 'Cause you can put your hat of like a dancer,
And make a better leg, than you were born to,
For to say truth your calf is well amended,
Must this so overtake me, that I must
Straight fall in love wi' ye, one step to church,
Another into the sheets, more to a bargain
You're wide a bow, and some thing over shot.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Then this is all that I must trust to, you
Will never ha' me?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: In my right mind, I think so;
Why, prithee tell me what I should do with thee?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Can you find nothing to do with me!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: To find any monkey spiders, were an office
Perhaps you would not execute!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: You're a Gipsy!
And none of the twelve Sibyls in a tavern,
Have such a tanned complexion, there be dogs
And horses in the world.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: They'll keep you company!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Tell me of spiders?
I'll wring your monkey's neck off.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: And then puzzle
Your brain to make an elegy, which shalbe sung
To the tune of the devil and the baker, good!
You have a pretty ambling wit in summer,
D'ye let out, or keep for your own
riding, who holds your stirrup, while you jump
Into a jest, to the endangering
Of your ingenious quodlibets.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Come thou'st said enough.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: To him, you would have some.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Some testimony of your love, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Indeed I have heard you are a precious gentleman,
And in your younger, could play at trap well.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Fare you well gentlewoman, by this light a devil,
I'll follow my old game of horse-racing.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I could tear her ruff! I would thou wert
A whore than I'd be revenged, and bring the prentices
To arraign thee on Shrove-tuesday, a pox upon you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: A third man, a third man, two fair gamesters.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: For shame let's go!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Will you stay gentleman; you ha' no more wit,
To venture, keep your heads warm in any case,
There may be dregs in the bottom o'the brain pan,
Which may turn to somewhat in seven years, and set
You up again, now sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Lady I am come to you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: It does appear so.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: To take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: 'Tis granted sir god buy.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But you must stay and hear a little more,
I promise not to trouble you with courtship,
I am as weary as you can be displeased wilt.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: On these conditions, I would have the patience
To hear the brazen head speak.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Whether, or how I purpose to dispose
Myself hereafter, as I know you have
No purpose to inquire, I have no great
Ambition to discourse, but how I have
Studied your fair opinion, I remit
To time, and come now only to request
That you would grant, in lieu of my true service
One boon at parting.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Forboon I proceed!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But you must swear to perform truely what
I shall desire, and that you may not think
I come with any cunning to deceive you,
You shall except whate'er you would deny me,
And after all I'll make request.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But it concerns my life, or what can else
Be nearer to me that you swear.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: To what?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: When you have made exceptions and thought,
What things in all the world you will exempt,
From my petition, I'll be confident
To tell you my desire.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: This is fair play!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I would not for an empire by a trick
Oblige you to perform, what should displease you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: This is a very strange request; are you in earnest;
Ere you begin shall I except? 'tis odds
But I may include, what you have a mind to, then
Where's your petition?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I will run that hazard.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You will, why look you; for a little mirth's sake,
And since you come so honestly, because
You sha'not say, I am composed of marble,
I do consent.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Swear!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I am not come to that,
I'll first set bounds to your request, and when
I have left nothing for you worth my grant,
I'll take a zealous oath to grant you any thing.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: You have me at your mercy!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: First, you sha'not
Desire that I should love you!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: That's first, proceed!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: No more but proceed, d'ye know what I say.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Your first exception forbids to ask
That you should love me.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: And you are contented.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I must be so.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: What in the name of wonder will he ask me,
You shall not desire me to marry you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: That's the second.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: You shall neither directly, nor indirectly with me to lie with you,
sp.l: Have I not clipped the wings of your conceit.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: That's the third.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: That's the third, is there anything a young man would desire of his miss, when he must neither love, marry, nor lie with her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: My suit is still untouched. (With her. ●

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Suit! if you have another suit 'tis out of fashion,
Ye cannot beg my state, yet I would willingly
Give part of that to be rid on thee.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Not one jewel.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You would not have me spoil my face, drink poison,
Or kill anybody .

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Goodness forbid that I should wish your danger.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Then you would not ha' me ride through the city naked,
As once a Princess of England did through Coventry.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: All my desires are modest.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You shall not beg my parrot nor entreat me
To fast, or wear a hair smock.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: None of these.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I wonot be confined to make me ready
At ten, and pray till dinner, I will play
At gleek as often as I please, and see
Plays when I have a mind to't and the races,
Though men should run Adamits before me.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: None of these trench on what I have to ask.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Why then I swear — stay
You sha'not ask me before company
How old I am, a question most untoothsome,
I know not what to say more, I'll not be
Bound from spring garden, and the sparagus.
I won't have my tongue tied up, when I've
A mind to jeer my suitors, among which
your worship shall not doubt to be remembered,
For I must have my humour, I am sick else;
I will not be compelled to hear your sonnets,
A thing before, I thought to advise you of,
Your words of hard concoction rude poetry
Have much impaired my health, try sense another while
And calculate some prose according to
The elevation of our pole at London,
As says the learned almanac — but come on
And speak your mind, I ha' done, I know not what
More to except, if it be none of these
And as you say feasible on my part,
I swear.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: By what.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: For once a kiss, it may be a parting blow,
By that I will perform what you desire.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: In few words thus receive it, by that oath
I bind you, never to desire my company
Hereafter, for no reason to affect me,
This I am sure was none of your exceptions.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: What has the man said?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: 'Tis clear, I am confident
To your understanding.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You have made me swear
That I must never love you, nor desire
Your company.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I know you will not violate,
What you have sworn, so all good thoughts possess you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Was all this circumstance for this? I never
Found any inclination to trouble him
With too much love, why should he bind me from it,
And make me swear, an oath that for the present,
I had no affection to him, had been reasonable,
But for the time to come, never to love,
For any cause or reason, that may move me
Hereafter, very strange, I know not what to think on't,
Although I never meant, to think well on him,
Yet to be limited, and be prescribed,
I must not do it? 'twas a poor trick in him,
But I'll go practise something to forget it.

div.head: The third act.
div.stage: Enter lord Bonvile, mistress Julietta, Fairefield, with their attendants.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Lady you're welcome to the spring, the park
Looks fresher to salute you, how the birds
On every tree sing; with more cheerfulness
At your access, as if they prophesied
Nature would die, and resign her providence
To you, fit only to succeed her.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You express
A master of all compliment, I have
Nothing but plain humility, my lord
To answer you.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: But I'll speak our own English,
Hang these affected strains, which we sometimes
Practice, to please the curiosity
Of talking ladies, by this lip thou'rt welcome,
I'll swear a hundred oaths upon that book,
An't please you.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: They are at it.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You shall not need my lord, I'm not incredulous.
I do believe your honour, and dare trust
For more than this.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I wonot breaken my credit
With any lady that dares trust me.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: She had a cruel heart, that would not venture
Upon the engagement of your honour.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What? what durst thou venture now, and be plain women

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: There's nothing in the verge of my command
That should not serve your lordship.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Speak, speak truth and flatter not,
Upon what security?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: On that which you propounded sir, your honour,
It is above all other obligation,
and he that's truly noble will not stain it.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Upon my honour will you lend me then
But a night's lodging.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: How sir.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: She is angry
I shall obtain, I know the trick on't, had
She yielded at the first it had been fatal.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: It seems your lordship speaks to one you know not.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: But I desire to know you better lady.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Better! I should desire my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Better or worse, if you dare venture one,
I'll hazard tother.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Tis your lordship's mirth.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You're in the right, 'tis the best mirth of all.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I'll not believe my lord you mean so wantonly
As you profess.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Refuse me if I do not
Not mean? I hope you have more charity
Than to suspect, I'll not perform as much,
And more than I ha' said, I know my fault,
I am too modest when I undertake,
But when I am to act let me alone.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You shall be alone no longer
My good lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Frank Tryer.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Which side holds your honour.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I am o'thy side Frank.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I think so! for
All the park's against me, but 6. to 4.
Is odds enough.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Is it so much against you.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Lady I think 'tis two, to one.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: We were on even terms till you came hither,
I find her yielding, and when they do run?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: They say presently.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Will you venture any thing lady?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Perhaps she reserves herself for the horse race.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: There I may venture somewhat with his lordship.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: That was a witty one.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You will be doing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are for the footmen.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I run with the company.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I'll go your half.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: No thank you Jack, would I had ten pieces more
On't.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Which side.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: On the Irishman.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Done! I'll maintain the English,
As many more with you, I love to cherish
Our own countrymen.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: 'Tis done my lord.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I'll rook for once, my lord I'll hold you twenty more

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Done with you too.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Your lordship is very confident.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I'll lay with you too.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Lie with her he means.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Come, you shall venture something,
What gold against a kiss, but if you lose,
You shall pay it formally down upon my lip.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Though she should win, it would be held extortion
To take your money.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Rather want of modesty,
A great sin if you observe the circumstance,
I see his lordship has a disposition
To be merry, but proclaim not this free say
To every one, some women in the world
Would hold you all day.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: But not all night sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Will you not see 'em my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Frank Tryar, you'll wait upon this gentlewoman,
I must among the gamesters, I shall quickly
Return to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: How d'ye like this gallant.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He's one it becomes not me to censure.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: D'ye not find him coming, a wild gentleman
you may in time convert him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You made me acquainted with him to that purpose,
It was your confidence, I'll do what I can,
Because he is your noble friend, and one
In whom was hid so much perfection
Of honour, for at first 'twas most invisible,
But it begins to appear, and I do perceive
A glimmering, it may break out a flame,
I shall know all his thoughts at our next conference,
He has a secret to impart he says
Only to me.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: And will you hear it?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Yes sir, if it be honourable there is no harm in't,
If otherwise you do not doubt my innocence.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: But do not tempt a danger.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: From his lordship.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I do not say from him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: From mine own frailty.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I dare not conclude that but from the matter
Of his discourse, on which there may depend
A circumstance that may not prove so happy.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Now I must tell you sir, I see your heart
Is not so just as I deserve, you have
Engaged me to his conversation,
Provoked by jealous thoughts, and now your fear
Betrays your want of goodness, for he never
Was right at home, that dare suspect his mistress,
Can love degenerate in noble breasts,
Collect the arguments, that could invite you
To this unworthy trial, bring them to
My forehead, where you shall inscribe their names
For virgins to blush at me, if I do not
Fairly acquit myself.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Nay be not passionate.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I am not sir so guilty to be angry,
But you shall give me leave unless you will
Declare, you dare not trust me any further,
Not to break off so rudely with his, lordship.
I will hear what he means to say to me,
And if my council may prevail with you,
You sha'not interrupt us, have but patience
I'll keep the story for you, and assure
My ends have no base mixture, not my love
To you could bribe me to the least dishonour,
Much less a stranger, since I have gone so far
By your commission, I will proceed
A little further at my peril sir.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I know thou art proof against a thousand engines,
Pursue what ways you please.

div.stage: Enter Lacy, mistress Bonavent. and mistress Caroll.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: This morning married?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: That your brother's mistress.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: She that jeers all within gunshot.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: In the way of suitors,
She is reported such a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: My brother.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Frank Tryer.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Brother do you know that gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: 'Tis she, than you and I must seem more familiar,
And you sha'not be angry.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What gentlewoman's that?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: She does not know thee.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Was this his reason, pray if you love me let's
Walk by that gentleman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Master Fairefeild.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Is that well trust gentleman one of them that run.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Ha, ha, I'd laugh at that!
If you allow a bushel of salt to acquaintance,
Pray vouchsafe two words to a bargain while you live
I scarce remember him, keep in great heart.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O sir you are very well met here.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: We are met indeed, sir thank you for your music.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It is not so much worth.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I made you merry master bridegroom.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I could not choose but laugh.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Be there any races here.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yes sir horse and foot.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: You'll give me leave to take my course then.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: This is the captain that did dance.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Not so nimbly as your wit, pray let men ask you a question.
I hear that gentlewoman's married.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Married without question sir.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: D'ye think he has been aforehand.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: How d'ye mean.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: In English has he played the forward gamester
And turned up trump.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Before the cards be shuffled?
I lay my life you mean a coat card
Deal again, you gave one to many
In the last trick, yet I'll tell thee what I think.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I think she and you might ha' shown more wit.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Why she and I?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: She to ha' kept herself a widow, and
You not to have asked me such a foolish question,
But if she had been half so wise, as in
My conscience she is honest, you had missed
That excellent occasion, to show
Your notable skill in dancing, but it pleased
The learned destinies to put things together,
And so we separate.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Fare ye well mistress.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Come hither, go to that gentleman Mr. Fairefeild.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Prithee sweet heart who runs?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: An Irish and an English footman?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Will they run this way?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Just before you, I must have a bet!

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nay, nay you sha'not leave me.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Do it discreetly, I must speak to him,
To ease my heart I shall burst else,
We'll expect 'em here, cousin, do they run naked?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: That were a most immodest sight.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Her● have been such fellows, cousin.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: It would fright the women!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Some are of opinion it brings us hither,
Hark what a confusion of tongues there is,
Let you and I venture a pair of gloves
Upon their feet, I'll take the Irish.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: 'Tis done, but you shall pay if you lose.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Here's my hand, you shall have the gloves if you win.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I think they are started.

div.stage: The runners, after them the gentlemen

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A teag, a teag, make way for shame.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I hold any man forty pieces yet.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: A hundred pound to ten, a hundred pieces to ten, will
No man take me?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I hold you sir.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Well you shall see, a teag a teag heigh.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Ha well run Irish.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: He may be in a bog anon.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Can they tell what they do in this noise,
Pray heaven it do not break into the tombs
At Westminster, and wake the dead.

div.stage: Enter master Fairefeild and his sister.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: She's yonder still, she thinks thee a new mistress.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I observe her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: How go things Frank.
Prithee observe that creature.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: She leers this way.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I ha' done such a strange cure upon her,
Sh'as sent for me, and I will entreat thee Frank
To be a witness of my triumph, 'tis
Now in my power to punish all her jeers,
But I'll go to her, thou shalt keep a distance
Only to hear, how most miraculously
I ha' brought things about.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: The cry returns.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Make way there, a teag, a teag, a teag.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Forty, fifty, a hundred pieces to ten.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I hold you.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Well you shall see, you shall see.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: This gentleman does nothing but talk, he makes good
No bet.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Talk? you prate, I'll make good what I please sir.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Make the best you can of that.

div.stage: They switch, and draw, and exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: For heaven's sake let's remove.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: What for a naked weapon!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Fight gentlemen, you're fine fellows, 'tis a noble cause,
Come lady I'll discharge your fears,
A cup of sack, and Anthony at the rose
Will reconcile their furies.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I make a doubt whether I should go to her,
Upon a single summons.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: By any means.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What women are forbidden
They're mad to execute, she's here, be you
It'h reach of her voice, and see how I will humble her.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: But keep at some fit distance.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: You honour me, and shall
Command me any service.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: He has gone a strange way to work with me.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Well advised, observe and laugh without a noise.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I am ashamed to think what I must say now.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: By your leave lady! I take it you sent for me?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You wonot be so impudent, ay, send for you ▪
By whom or when?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Your servant —

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Was a villain if he mentioned
I had any such desire, he told me indeed
You courted him to entreat me that I would
Be pleased to give you another audience,
And that you swore, I know not what confound you,
You would not trouble me above six words.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: You are prettily disposed.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: With much ado you see I have consented,
What is't you would say?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Nay, what is't, you would say?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Be you no prompter to insinuate
The first word of your studied oration,
He's out on's part, come, come I'll imagine it,
Was it not something to this purpose — lady,
Or mistress, or what you will, although
I must confess; you may with justice laugh at
My most ridiculous suit, and you will say
I am a fool.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: You may say any thing.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: To come again , whom you have so tormented,
For ne'er was simple camomile so trod on,
Yet still I grow in love, but since there is
No hope to thaw your heart, I now am desperate,
O give me, lend me but the silken tie,
About your leg, which some do call a garter,
To hang myself, and I am satisfied, am not I a witch.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I think thou'rt past it,
Which of the furies art thou made already,
I shall depart the world, ne'er fear it lady,
Without a necklace, did not you send for me.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I shall laugh a loud sir.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: What madness has
Possessed you? have I not sworn you know by what,
Never to think well of you, of all men
Living, not to desire your company,
And will you still intrude, shall I be haunted
For ever, no place give me privilege;
O man what art thou come to?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: O woman!
How far thy tongue and heart do live asunder,
Come; I ha' found you out, off with this veil,
It hides not your complexion, I do tell thee,
I see thy heart, and every thought within it,
A little peevishness to save your credit
had not been much amiss, but this over
Over doing the business it appears
Ridiculous, like my suit as you inferred,
But I forgive thee and forget thy tricks
And trillabubs, and will swear to love thee
Heartily; wenches must ha' their ways.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, if I have seemed too light,
It was not rudeness from my heart, but a
Disguise to save my honour if I found
You still incredulous.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I love thee better
For thy vagaries.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: In vain I see I should dissemble w'ee,
I must confess you've caught me, had you still
Pursued the common path, I had fled from you,
You found the constitution of women
In me, whose will, not reason is their law,
Most apt to do, what most they are forbidden,
Impatient of curbs in their desires.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Thou sayest right.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: O love I am thy captive, but I am forsworn ▪
Am I not sir?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Ne'er think of that.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Ne'er think on't.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: 'Twas a vain oath, and well may be dispensed with,

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: O sir, be more religious, I never
Did violate an oath in all my life,
Though I ha' been wild, I had a care of that,
An oath's a holy obligation,
And never dreaming of this chance, I took it
With true intention to perform your wishes,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: 'Twas but a kiss, I'll give it thee again.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: But 'tis enrolled in that high court already,
I must confess, I could look on you now
With other eyes, for my rebellious heart
Is soft and capable of love's impression,
Which may prove dangerous, if I cherish it,
Having forsworn your love.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Now I am fitted.
I have made twigs to jerk myself — well thought on
You shall absolve yourself, your oath does not
Oblige you to perform what you excepted,
And among them, if you remember, you
Said you must have your humour you'd be sick else,
Now if your humour be to break your oath
Your obligation's void.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You have relieved me!
But do not triumph in your conquest sir,
Be modest in your victory.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Will not you
Fly off again, now you're at large.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: If you
Suspect it, call some witness of my vows,
I will contract myself.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: And I am provided,
Frank Tryer appear, and show thy physiognomy,
He is a friend of mine, and you may trust him.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: What sum of money is it you would borrow.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I borrow?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: This gentleman your friend has fully
Possessed me with your wants, nay do not blush,
Debt is no sin, though my own money's sir
Are all abroad, yet upon good security,
Which he answers you can put in, I will
Speak to a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What security?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Yourselves, and two sufficient aldermen,
For men are mortal and may break.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You shall have fifty pounds for forty weeks
To do you a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: You'll not use me thus?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Fare you well, you have miraculously brought things about.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You work by stratagem and ambuscado.
Do you not think yourself a proper gentleman,
Whom by your want of hair some hold a wit too,
you know my heart, and every thought within it
How I am caught, do I not melt like honey
It'h dog days, why do you look so staring.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Do not you love me for all this?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Would I had art enough to draw your picture,
It would show rarely at the exchange, you have
A medley in your face of many nations,
Your nose is Roman, which your next debauchment,
At tavern with the help of pot or candlestick
May turn to Indian flat, your lip is Austrian,
And you do well to bit it; for your chin
It does incline to the Bavarian poke,
But seven years may disguise it with a beard,
And make it more ill favoured; you have eyes
Especially when you goggle thus, not much
Unlike a Jews, and yet some men might take 'em
For Turks, by the two half moons that rise about 'em,
I am an infidel to use him thus.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Till now I never was myself, farewell
For ever woman, not worth love or anger.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: D'ye hear one word,
I'd fain speak kindly to him,
Why dost not rail at me?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: No, I will laugh at thee and at myself,
To have been so much a fool, you're a fine may game.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I shall fool too much, but one word more,
By all the faith and love of womankind,
Believe me now, it wonot out.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Farewell
When next I dote upon thee be a monster.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Hark sir the nightingale, there is better luck
Coming towards us.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: When you are out of breath
You will give over, and for better luck,
I do believe the bird, for I can leave thee,
And not be in love with my own torment.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: How sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I ha' said, stay you and practise with the bird,
'twas Philomel they say, and thou wert one,
I should new ravish thee.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I must to th' coach and weep, my heart will break else,
I'm glad he does not see me.

div.head: The fourth act.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Whither will you walk my lord? you may engage
Yourself too far and lose your sport!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I would
Go farther for a little sport, you mean
The horse race, they're not come into the park yet,
I might do something else, and return time
Enough to five hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Your lordship had no fortune in the last match,
I wished your confidence a happier success.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: We must lose sometimes — hark the nightingale

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You win my lord I dare engage myself.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You make the omen fortunate, this bird
Doth prophesy good luck.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Tis the first time I heard it.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: And I this spring, let's walk a little further .

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I am not weary but —

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You may trust your person lady.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I were too much wicked to suspect your honour
And in this place.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: This place, the place were good enough
If you were bad enough, and as prepared
As I, there have been storeys that some have
Struck many dear within the park:

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Foul play,
If I did think your honour had a thought
To venture at unlawful game, I should
Ha brought less confidence.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Ha Tryer,
What does he follow us?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: To show I dare
Be bold upon your virtue, take no notice
I'll waft him backe again, my lord walk forward.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Thus far alone? yet why do I suspect?
Hang jealousy 'tis naught, it breeds too many
Worms in our brains, and yet she might ha' suffered me,
Master Lacy, and his bride!

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I was wont to have one always in my chamber.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou shalt have a whole choir of nightingales.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I heard it yesterday warble so prettily.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They say 'tis lucky, when it is the first
Bird that salutes our ear.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Do you believe it.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I am of his mind, and love a happy augury.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Observe the first note always
Cuckoo?
Is this the nightingale?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Why do you look so?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Are not we married,
I wood not have been a bachelor to have heard it.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To them they say 'tis fatal.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: And to married men
Cuckoo is no delightful note, I shall
Be superstitious.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Let's walk a little further.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I wait upon thee, hark still ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I am not much in love with the broad ditty.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Frank Tryer, I ha' been seeking thee
About the park.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: What to do,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: To be merry for half an hour, I find
A scurvy melancholy creep upon me,
I'll try what sack will do, I ha' sent my footman
To th' Maurice for a bottle, we shall meet him,
I'll tell thee tother story of my lady.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I'll wait on you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: But that she is my sister,
I'd ha' thee forswear women, but let's walk.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: This way they marched, I hope they wonot leap
The pale, I do not know the disposition
Of my capering gentleman, and therefore two not
Be indiscretion to observe him, things
Must be a little better reconciled,
The nightingale — this can presage no hurt,
But I shall lose my pigeons, they are in view
Fair and far off.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: He must be a Pegasus that beats me.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Yet your confidence may deceive you, you will tide
Against a jockey, that has horsemanship.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: A jockey, a jackanapes a horseback rather,
A monkey or a masty dog would show
A giant to him, and I were Alexander
I would lay the world upon my mare, she shall
Run with the devil for a hundred pieces,
Make the match who will.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Not I, you shall excuse me,
Nor would I win his money.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Whose?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: The devils, my gold has burned this 12. months in my pocket,
A little of his amongst, would scorch my thighs
And make such tinder of my linings, that
My breeches never after, would hold money,
But let these pass; where's Lacy and his bride?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: They are walked to hear the nightingale.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: The nightingale? I ha' not heard one this year ▪

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Listen, and we shall hear one presently,
Cuckoo.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: The bird speaks to you.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: No 'tis to you.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now do I suspect
I shall lose the race.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Despair for a cuckoo.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: A cuckoo won't flatter,
His word will go before a gentleman's
it'h city? 'tis an understanding bird
And seldom fails, a cuckoo, I'll hedge in
My money presently.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: For shame be confident.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Will you go half.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I'll go it all, or any thing.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Hang cuckoos then.
My lord, Bonvile, Lacy, and his bride!

div.stage: Enter lo. Bon. Lacy, mistress Fairefeild, mistress Bona.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How now gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Your honour's servants.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Ladies, I kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You are the man, will run away with all
The gold anon.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Your jockey must fly else.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I'll hold your honour thirty pieces more.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Do you ride yourself.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I shall have the reins in my own hand lady.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Master rider, saw you not my cousin.
Cry mercy she is here, I thought y'ad followed us.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Your kinswoman,
I shall be honoured to be your servant lady.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Alas my lord you'll lose by't!
What?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Honour me being my servant! here's a brace ▪
Of gentlemen will tell you as much.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: But will say nothing for our credits.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You look as you had wept.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I weep! For what?
Come towards the lodge, and drink a syllabub.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A match!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And as we walk, Jack venture thou shalt sing,
The song thou mad'st o'th' horses.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: You shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: What among friends? my lord if you'd speak to him.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: A song by all means, prithee, let me
Entreat it, what's the subject ▪

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Of all the running horses.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Horses and mares put them together.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Let's have't, come I heard you can sing rarely.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: An excellent voice.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A ravishing tone.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: 'Tis a very ballad my lord, and a course tune.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: The better, why does any tune become
A gentleman so well as a ballad, hang
Curiosity in music, leave those crotchets
To men that get their living with a song,
Come come begin.

lg.l: Come muses all that dwell nigh the fountain,
Made by the winged horse's heel,
Which firked with his rider over each mountain,
Let me your galloping raptures feel.
I do not sing of fleas, or frogs,
Nor of the well mouthed hunting dogs.
Let me be just all praises must,
Be given to well breathed Jilian thrust.
Young constable and kill deers famous,
The cat the mouse and noddy grey,
With nimble Pegabrig you cannot shame us,
With Spaniard nor with Spinola.
Hill climbing white-rose, praise doth not lack,
Handsome Dunbar, and yellow Jack.
But if I be just all praises must,
Be given to well breathed lilian thrust.
Sure spurred sloven, true running robin,
Of young shaver I do not say less,
Strawberry soame, and let spider pop in,
Fine Brackly and brave lurching Bess.
Victorious too, was herring shotten,
And spit in's arse is not forgotten.
But if I be just all honour must
Be given to well breathed Jilian thrust.
Lusty gorge and gentlemen, hark yet,
To winning mackerell fine mouthed freak,
Bay Tarrall that won the cup at Newmarket,
Thundering tempest, black dragon eke.
Precious sweet lipps, I do not lose,
Nor Toby with his golden shoes,
But if I be just, all honour must,
Be given to well breathed Jilian thrust.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Excellent, how think you lady?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I like it very well.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I never thought you were a poet sir.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: No no, I do but dabble.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You can sing early too, how were these parts
Observed, invisible?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: You may see lady.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Good sir your pardon ▪

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Do you love singing, hum, la la.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Who would ha' thought these qualities were in you,

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now or never.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Why I was cozened.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: You are not the first I ha' cozened, shall I wash
Your faces with the drops of Helicon, I ha' fancies in my head.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Like Jupiter you want a Vulcan but
To cleave your skull, and out peeps bright Minerva.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: When you return I'll tell you more my lord.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Give me a subject.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Prithee coz do.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Let it be how much you dare suffer for me.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Enough — hum, fa, la la.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Master venture you're expected.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Are they come?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: This half hour my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I must see the mare, you will excuse this rudeness,
Sirrah stay you and wait upon these ladies.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: 'Tis time to make me ready,
Ladies I take this leave in prose,
You shall see me next in other feet.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I wish your syllabub were nectar lady.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: We thank you sir, and here it comes already.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: So so, is it good milk?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Of a red cow.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You talk as you inclined to a consumption,
Is the wine good?

sp.speaker: Milkmaid
sp.l: It comes from his excellence head!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: My service to you lady, and to him
Your thoughts prefer.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A health!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: No deep one? 'tis lawful for gentlewomen
To wish well to their friends.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You have obliged me — the wishes of all happiness
To him you heart hath chosen.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Duty now ▪
Requires I should be willing to receive it
As many joys to you both, when you are married.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Married?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You have not vowed to die a virgin,
I know an humble servant of yours lady?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Mine!

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Would be sorry you should be a nun.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: D'ye think he loves me then?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I do not think
He can dissemble where he does profess
Affection: I know his heart by mine;
Fairfield is my brother!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Your brother? then the danger's not so great, but
Let us change our argument: with your pardon,
Come hither pretty one; how old are you?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I am young lady, I hope you do not take me for a
Dwarf.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How young I pray then?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Four summers since my life was questioned,
And then a jewry of years did pass upon me.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: He is upon the matter then, fifteen.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: A game at noddy.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You can play your cards already it seems, come drink●
A this syllabub!

sp.speaker: Page ▪
sp.l: I shall spoil your game ladies, for if there be sack
In't it may make you flush a three.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The boy would seem witty.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I hope ladies you will pardon me, my lord
Commanded me to wait upon you, and
I can do you no better service, than
To make you laugh.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: They're here, bless you!

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Master Fairfield you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I presume so, but howsoever it skills not.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I do not come to borrow money.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: And yet all they that do so are no fools,
Money or lands make not a man the wiser,
I know handsome gentlemen ha' pawned
Their clothes.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I'll pawn my skin too with a woman.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Wipe your mouth, here's to you sir!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I'll pledge ye quicksilver, where's your lord?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: He has left virgo sir, to go to Libra,
To see the horsemen weighed.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Lady my service!

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Brother, you interpose too far, my lord
Has used me honourably, and I must tell you
