Somebody has made a fault.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Master Fairfield!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: My lord and you have walked.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: My sister shall excuse, here's to thee and thy cream bowl.

sp.speaker: Milkmaid
sp.l: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: There is more honesty in thy petticoat
Than twenty satin ones.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Do you know that?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I know by her pale, and she were otherwise
'Twould turn her milk, come hither let me kiss thee,
Now I am confirmed, he that shall marry thee
Shall take thee a virgin at my peril.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Ha you such skill in maidenheads.

sp.speaker: Fa
sp.l: I'll know't by a kiss,
Better than any doctor by her urine,
Be merry with thy cow, farewell! come Frank,
That wit and good clothes should infect a woman.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I'll tell you more hereafter, pray let's hear
Who wins.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Your servant ladies.
What dost think jockey.
The crack oth' field against you

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Let 'em crack nuts.
What weight.
I think he has the heels.
Get but the start.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: However if I get within his quarters let me alone.
Mounts chevall.

div.stage: Confused noise of betting within, after that a shout.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: They are started.

div.stage: Enter Bonvile, rider, Bona. Try. Fairef.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Twenty pounds to fifteen.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: 'Tis done w'ye.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Forty pounds to thirty.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Done, done, I'll take all odds.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: My lord I hold as much.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Not so.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Forty pounds to twenty.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Done, done.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: You ha' lost all my lord, and it were a million.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: In your imagination, who can help it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Venture had the start and keeps it.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Gentlemen you have a fine time to triumph,
'Tis not your odds that makes you win.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Shall we venture nothing oth' horses,
What odds against my lord?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Silk stockings.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: To a pair of presumed gloves I take it.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Done!

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And I as much.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Done with you both!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I'll have 'em Spanish scent.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The stockings shall be scarlet, if you choose
Your scent, I'll choose my colour.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: 'Tis done, if venture
Knew but my lay it would half break his neck now,
And crying a jockey hay.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Is the wind in that coast, hark the noise.
Is jockey now?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: 'Tis but a pair of gloves.
Within a jockey.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Still it holds.
How ha' you sped my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Won, won, I known by instinct,
The mare would put some trick upon him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Then we ha' lost, but good my lord the circumstance.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Great John at all adventure and grave jockey
Mounted their several mares, I sha'not tell
The story out for laughing, ha, ha, ha,
But this in brief jockey was left behind,
The pity and the scorn of all the odds,
Played bout my ears like cannon, but less dangerous.
I took all still, the acclamations was
For venture, whose disdainful mare threw dirt
In my old jockey's face, all hopes forsaking us,
Two hundred pieces desperate, and two thousand
Oaths sent after them, upon the sudden,
When we expected no such trick, we saw
My rider that was domineering ripe,
Vault o'er his mare into a tender slough,
Where he was much beholding to one shoulder,
For saving of his neck, his beast recovered,
And he by this time somewhat mortified,
besides mortified, hath left the triumph
To his Olympic adversary, who shall
Ride hither in full pomp on his Bucephalus
With his victorious bagpipe.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I would fain see how venture looks.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: He's here, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I told you as much before, you would not
Believe the cuckoo.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Why, how now sir!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: And I had broke my neck in a clean way,
'Twould ne'er ha' grieved me, lady I am yours,
Thus Caesar fell.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Not in a slough dear Jack.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: You shall hear further from me.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Come to Knightsbridge.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: That cuckoo was a witch I'll take my death on't.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Here comes the conqueror

div.stage: A bagpipe playing, and jockey, Bonavent. Tryer, and Fairefeild.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: From the conquest of Jerusalem
Returns Vespasian, etc. ha, ha, mere mercy jockey.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I told you if I came within his quarters,
Omnes. A jockey, a jockey.

div.stage: Exeunt all by Lacy, his bride, mistress Caroll, enter Bonavent. and the bagpiper.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: This shall be but your earnest, follow me
At pretty distance, and when I say draw,
Play me a galliard, by your favour sir,
Shall I speak a cool word with ye.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: You do owe me a dance if you remember,
And I will have it now, no dispute, draw!
That wonot serve your turn, come shake your heels,
You hear a tune, I will not change my tool,
For a case of rapiers, keep off at your perils
I ha' sworn.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: For heaven's sake some to part 'em.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Dost hear.

sp.speaker: M. Bo.
sp.l: And you may hear the bagpipe is not dumb,
Will you to this gear, or do you mean to try
How this will scour you, come, come, I'll have it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hold, I will!

div.stage: He dances, mean time comes in my lord and Tryer.

sp.speaker: M. Bo.
sp.l: So, now we are on even terms, and if
You like it not, I'll use my tother instrument.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou'rt a brave fellow, come your ways.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Hold! you sha'not fight, I'll understand
Your quarrel.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good my lord let's have one pass.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your weapons shall run through me,
And I must tell you sir, have been injurious.

sp.speaker: M. Bo.
sp.l: Good lady why? in doing myself right.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: In wronging me.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I am not sensible of that.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Could any shame be fastened upon him
Wherein I have no share.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I was provoked
By him if you remember, and was not
Born so unequal to him I should suffer
His poor affront.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: This was a day of peace,
The day wherein the holy priest hath tied
Our hearts together, Hymen's tapers yet
Are burning, and it cannot be a sin
Less than a sacrilege, to extinguish them
With blood, and in contempt of heavens proceeding
Thus to conspire our separation
No christian would profane the marriage day,
And when all other wish us joys, could you
Intrude yourself to poison all our mirth,
Blast in the very bud all our happiness
Our hopes had laid up for us.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I was a stranger,

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: That makes ye more uncivil, we were merry
Which could not offend you.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I had no thought
to violate your mirth.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What came you for?
With whom had ye acquaintance, or what favour
Gave you access, at so unfit a time
To interrupt our calm and free delights;
You cannot plead any abuse, where you
Were never known, that should incite you to
Revenge it there, I take it you were never
His rival.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: 'Tis confessed!

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What malice then
Prevailed above your reason to pursue us
With this injustice?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Lady, give me leave!
I were a villain to be guilty of
The baseness you accuse me? your servant
Shall quit me from intrusion, and my soul
Is my best witness, that I brought no malice
But unstained thoughts into your roof, but when
I was made the common laughter, I had been
Less than a man, to think of no return
And had he been the only of my blood,
I would not be so much the shame of soldier
To have been rammed and suffered, and you are
Too hasty in your judgement, I could say
More, but 'tis dishonour to expostulate
These causes with a woman, I had reason
To call him to account, you know not all
My provocation, things are not with me as with another man.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How is that? the matter
May spread too far, some former quarrel, 'tis
My best to reconcile 'em, sir I may
Be ignorant if any thing have passed
Before this morning, I pray pardon me
But as you are a gentleman, let me ▪
Prevail, your differences may here conclude;
Alas I am part of him now, and between
A widow and his wife, if I be thus
divorced —

sp.speaker: M. b.
sp.l: I'll be his servant.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Sir you show
A noble disposition, good my lord
Compose their differences, prithee meet his friendship.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I have satisfaction, and desire his love.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou'st done but like a gentleman, thy hand
I'll love thee while I live.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Why so all friends.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: I meet it with a heart, and for disturbing
Your mirth today.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, no disturbance.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Then give me but the favour
To show I wish no sorrow to the bride,
I have a small oblation, which she must
Accept, or I shall doubt we are not friends,
'Tis all I have to offer at your wedding.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: There's my hand to justify it at fit time,
Peruse it, my lord I shall be studious
How to deserve your favour.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I am yours.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My lord let me obtain, you'll honour me
Tonight .
I was taken by a Turkish pirate, and detained many years
A prisoner in an island, where I had died his captive,
Had not a worthy merchant thence redeemed and furnished me,
Blessed delivery.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: To me? from venture he is very mindful, good,
I shall make use of this.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Till then conceal me.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Excellent stuff, but I must have another
Name subscribed.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Will you walk ladies.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Your servants wait upon

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: We humbly thank your honour.
A brave spark.
Spark, he's the very bonfire of nobility.

div.head: The fifth act.
div.stage: Enter Lacy, mistress Bonavent, Bonvile, mistress Fairefield, mistress Caroll, Tryer.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My lord you honour us.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And what we want
In honourable entertainment, we beseech
Our duties may supply in your construction.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What needs this ceremony.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou art welcome too Frank Tryer.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I give you thanks, and wish you still more joy sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: We'll show your lordship a poor gallery.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But where's my new acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: His nag outstripped the coaches,
He'll be your guest anon, fear not!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: While they compliment with my lord, let you and I
Change a few words.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: As many as you please.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Then to the purpose
Touching your brother, lady,
'Twere tedious to repeat, he has been pleased
To think well of me, and to trouble you
With the discourse how I have answered it
'Twere vain, but thus howe'er he seem to carry it
While you were present, I do find him desperate.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Nay I speak no conjecture, I have more
Intelligence than you imagine, you are his sister,
And nature binds you to affect his safety,
By some convenient messenger send for him;
But as you love his life do not delay it;
Alas I shall be sorry, any gentleman
Should for my sake take any desperate course.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: But are you serious?

sp.speaker: Ca,
sp.l: Perhaps good counsel
Applied while his despair is green may cure him,
If not?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You make me wonder.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I know the inconsiderate will blame
Me for his death, I shall be railed upon
And have a thousand cruelties thrown on me,
But would you have me promise love and flatter him?
I would do much to save his life, I could
Show you a paper, that would make you bleed
To see his resolution, and what
Strange and unimitable ways he has
Vowed to pursue, I tremble to think on 'em.
There's not a punishment in fiction
And poets write enough of hell, if you
Have read their story, but he'll try the worst,
Were it not that I fear him every minute.
And that all haste were requisite to save him,
You should peruse his letter.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Letter! since we saw him ▪

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Since, I must confess, I wondered,
But you in this shall see I have no malice,
I pray send for him, as I am a gentlewoman
I have pure intention to preserve his life;
And cause I see the truth of his affliction,
Which may be yours or mine, or anybody's
Whose passions are neglected, I will try
My best skill to reduce him, here's m. Tryer!
He now depends upon your charity,
Send for him by the love you bear a brother.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Will you not chide my want of manners gentlewomen
To interrupt your dialogue

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: We ha' done sir.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I shall be still your servant.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Here's a riddle; but I will do't,
Shall I presume upon you for a favour.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You shall impose on me a greater trouble
My lord, your care ▪

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: We miss you above lady.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: My lord I wait upon you, I beseech
Your pardon but a minute — will you do this,
It is an office he may thank you for,
Beside my acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Yes I'll go
And yet I do not like to be sent oft,
This is the second time.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Now I am for your lordship,
What's your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I would be your echo lady, and return
Your last word — pleasure.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: May you never want it.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: This wonot serve my turn.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: This is the charity of some rich men,
That passing by some monument that stoops
With age, whose ruins plead for a repair
Pity the fall of such a goodly pile,
But will not spare from their superfluous wealth
To be the benefactor.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I acknowledge
That empty wishes are their shame, that have
Ability to do a noble work,
And fly the action.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Come! you may apply it,
I would not have you a gentlewoman of your word
Alone, they're deeds that crown all, what you wish me
Is in your own ability to give;
You understand me; will you at length consent
To multiply, we'll point a place and time,
And all the world shall envy us.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: My lord!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Lord me no lords, shall we enjoy lips upon't,
Why do you look as you still wondered at me,
Do I not make a reasonable motion,
Is't only in myself, sha'not you share
I'the delight, or do I appear a monster
Above all mankind, you shun my embrace thus ▪
there be some ladies in the world ha' drawn
Cuts for me, I ha' been talked on and commended,
Howe'er you please to value me.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Did they see you thus perfectly.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Not always, 'twas
Sometimes a little darker when they praised me,
I have the same activity.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You are
Something, I would not name my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: And yet you do, you call me lord, that's something
And you consider, all men are not born to't.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Twere better not to have been born to honours,
Than forfeit 'em so poorly, he is truly
Noble, and best justifies his blood
When he can number the descents of virtue.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You'll not degrade me.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Tis not in my power
Or will my lord, and yet you press me strangely
As you're a person, separate and distinct
By your high blood, above me and my fortunes
Thus low I bend, you have no noble title
Which I not bow to, they are characters
Which we should read at distance, and there is
Not one that shall with more devotion
And honour of your birth, express her service,
It is my duty, where the King has sealed
His favours, I should show humility
My best obedience to his act.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: So should
All handsome women that will be good subjects.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: But if to all those honourable names,
That marked you for the people's reverence,
In such a vicious age, you dare rise up
Example too of goodness, they which teach
Their knees a compliment, will give their heart,
And I among the number of the humblest.
Most proud to serve your lordship, and would refuse
No office or command, that should engage me
to any noble trial, this addition
Of virtue is above all shine of state,
And will draw more admirers; but I must
Be bold to tell you sir, unless you prove
A friend to virtue were your honour centupled,
Could you pile titles till you reach the clouds.
Were every petty manor you possess
A kingdom, and the blood of many princes
United in your veins, with these had you
A person that had more attraction
Than poesy can furnish, love withal,
Yet I, I in such infinite distance am
As much above you in my innocence.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: This becomes not.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Tis the first liberty
I ever took to speak myself, I have
Been bold in the comparison, but find not
Wherein I have wronged virtue, pleading for it.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How long will you continue thus?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I wish
To have my last hour witness of these thoughts,
And I will hope before that time, to hear
Your lordship of another mind.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I know not,
'Tis time enough to think o'that hereafter,
I'll be a convertite within these two days,
Upon condition you and I may have
One bout tonight , nobody hears.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Alas you plunge too far, and are within this minute,
Further from heaven then ever.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I may live
To require the courtesy.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Live my lord to be
Your country's honour and support, and think not
Of these poor dreams.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I find not desire to sleep, and I were a-bed we.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Tis not improbable my lord but you
May live to be an old man, and fill up
a seat among the grave nobility,
When your cold blood shall starve your wanton thoughts.
And your slow pulse beat like your body's knell,
When time hath snowed upon your hair, o then
Will it be any comfort to remember
The sins of your wild youth, how many wives,
Or virgins you've dishonoured? in their number,
Would any memory of me (Should I
Be sinful to consent) not fetch a tear,
From you perhaps a sigh to break your heart,
Will you not wish than you had never mixed
With atheists, and those men whose wits are vented
In oaths and blasphemy, now the pride of gentlemen,
That strike at heaven, and make again of thunder.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: If this be true? what a wretched thing should I
Appear now, if I were any thing but a lord,
I do not like myself, give me thy hand
Since there is no remedy, be honest! there's no harm
I'this I hope, I wonot tell thee all
My mind at once, if I do turn carthusian,
And renounce flesh upon this, the devil is like
Toha the worst on't — but I am expected.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: My lord I'll follow ye.
Brother welcome?
Sir we are both obliged to you
A friend of yours desirers some private conference.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: With me?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He does not look so desperate; how d'ye brother?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Well — dost not see me?
I'll come to thee presently.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What's the meaning?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Nay I know not, she is full of mysteries a late;
She's here again, there is some trick in't.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Brother I sent for you, and I think 'twas time,
Pray harken to this gentlewoman; she will
Give you good council, you and I withdraw sir.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Whither you please.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You're a strange gentleman,
Alas, what do you mean? is it because
I have dealt justly with you, without flattery
Told you my heart, you'll take these wicked courses?
But I am loath to chide, yet I must tell you
You're too, too blame, alas you know affection
Is not to be compelled, I have been as kind
To you as other men, nay I still thought.
A little better of you, and will you
Give such example to the rest,
Because forsooth, I do not love you,
Will you be desperate?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I will be desperate!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: 'Twere a fine credit for you, but perhaps
You'll go to hell to be revenged oh me,
And teach the other gentlemen to follow ye,
That men may say 'twas long of me and rail at
My unkindness, is this all your christianity?
Or could you not prosecute your impious purpose,
But you must send me word on't, and perplex
My conscience with your devilish devices
Is this a letter to be sent a mistress?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I send a letter?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You were best deny your hand.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: My names subscribed, who has done this?
Rivers of hell I come, Charon thy oar
Is needless, I will swim unto the shore,
And beg of Pluto, and of Proserpine,
That all the damned torments may be mine,
With Tantalus I'll stand up to the chin
In waves, upon Ixion's wheel I'll spin
The sister's thread, quail Cerberus with my groan,
And take no physic, for the rolling stone
I'll hang myself, a hundred times a day.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: There be short days in hell.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: And burn myself as often if you say
The word.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Alas not I.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: And if I ever chance to come
Within the confines of Elysium,
The amazed ghosts shall be aghast to see,
How I will hang myself on every tree,
Here's a strange resolution.

div.stage: Yours till his neck be broke, Fairefeild.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Is it not?
Whither is fled your piety! but sir
I have no meaning to exasperate
Thoughts that oppose your safety, and to show
I have compassion, and delight in no
Man's ruin, I will frame myself to love you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Will you? why thank you! '

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Here's my hand I will;
Be comforted, I have a stronger faith.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I see than you have charity for an need.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I'll lose my humour to preserve a life,
You might ha' met with some hard hearted mistress,
That would a suffered you to hang or drown
Yourself.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I might indeed.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: And carried news
To the distressed ghosts, but I am merciful,
But do not you mistake me, for I do not
This out of any extraordinary
Former good will, only to save your life.
There be so many beams convenient,
And you may slip out of the world before
We are aware, beside you dwell too near
The river, if you should be melancholy
After some tides, you would come in, and be
More talked off then the pilchards, but I ha' done:
You sha'not go to hell for me, I now
Am very serious, and if you please
To think well of me instantly we'll marry,
I'll see how I can love you afterwards,
Shall's to the priest?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: By your good favour, no
I am in no such tune.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You do suspect
I jeer still? by my troth I am in earnest.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: To save my life you are content to marry me,
Yes.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: To save thy life, I will not be troubled with thee!
How?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: No madam jeer all, I am now resolved,
Talk, and talk out thy heart, I won't lose
Myself a scruple, ha you no more letters,
They're pretty mirth, would I knew who subscribed
My name ▪ I am so far from hanging of myself,
That I will five yet to be thy tormenter,
Virtue I thank thee for't, and for the more
Security, I'll never dote again;
Nor marry, nor endure the imaginations
Of your frail sex, this very height I will
Be fitted for you all, I'll geld myself,
'Tis something less than hanging, and when I
Have carved away all my concupiscence,
Observe but how I'll triumph, nay I'll do't,
And there were no more men in the world.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Sir, sir, as you love goodness
I'll tell you all, first hear me, and then execute,
You wonot be so foolish, I do love you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I hope so, that I may revenge thy peevishness.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: My heart is full, and modesty forbids
I should use many words, I see my folly,
You may be just, and use me with like cruelty,
But if you do I can instruct myself,
And be as miserable indeed as I
Made you in supposition, my thoughts
Point upon no sensuality, remit
What's past, and I will meet your best affection,
I know you love me still, do not refuse me.
If I go once more back, you ne'er recover me.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I am as ticklish.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Then let's clapped up wisely,
While we are both i'th humour, I do find
a grudging, and your last words stick in my stomach
Say is't a match? speak quickly, or for ever
Hereafter hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Done!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Why done!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Seal and deliver.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: My hand and heart, this shall suffice till morning.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Each others now by conquest, come let's to 'em
If you should false now.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Hold me not worth the hanging.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I knew not, she was thy mistress, which encouraged
All my discourses.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: My lord you've richly satisfied me, and
Now I dare write myself, the happiest lover
In all the world, know lady I ha' tried you.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You have it seems.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: And I have found thee right
And perfect gold, nor will I change thee for
A crown imperial.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: And I have tried you,
And found you dross, nor do I love my heart
So ill, to change it with you.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Unworthily you have suspected me,
And cherished that bad humour, for which know
You never must have hope to gain my love,
He that shall doubt my virtue, out of fancy,
Merits my just suspicion and disdain.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: O fie Frank, practise jealousy so soon,
Distrust the truth of her thou lovest, suspect
Thy own heart sooner, what I have said I have
My pardon for; thou wert a wife for him
Whose thoughts were never corrupted.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: 'Twas but a trial and may plead for pardon.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I pray deny me not that liberty,
I will have proof too, of the man I choose
My husband, believe me, if men be
at such a loss of goodness I will value
Myself, and think no honour equal to
Remain a virgin.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I have made a trespass
Which if I cannot expiate, yet let me
Dwell in your charity.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You shall not doubt that.
sp.stage: Enter Fairefield, mistress Caroll, Lacy, mistress Bon.
sp.l: Pray my lord know him for your servant.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I am much honoured.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You cannot but deserve more by the title of her brother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Another couple.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Master Fairfield and my cousin are contracted.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: 'Tis time I think, sister I'll shortly call you.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I ever wished it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Frank Tryer is melancholy, how hast thou sped?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: No no I am very merry.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Our banes sir are forbidden.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: On what terms?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My lord you meet but a course entertainment,
How chance the music speaks not, shall us dance?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Rivers of hell I come!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Charon thy oar is needless, save you gallants!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I will swim unto thy shore, art not thou Hero.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: But you are not Leander if you be not drowned,
In the Hellespont.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I told thee I would drown myself a hundred times a day

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Your letter did.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: A ha?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: It was a devilish good one.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Then I am come
To tickle the confines of Elysium,
My lord I invite you to my wedding,
And all this good company.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I am glad your shoulder is recovered;
When is the day?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Do thou set the time.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: After tomorrow, name it, this gentleman
And I shall be married i'th morning, and you know
We must have a time to dine, and dance to bed.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Married?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yes you may be a guest sir, and be welcome.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I am bobbed again,
I'll bob for no more eels, let her take her course.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O for some willow garlands.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: This is my boy, how now sirrah?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: My lord I am employed in a device;

lg.l: Room for the melancholy wight,
Some do call him willow knight,
Who this pains hath under taken,
To find out lovers are forsaken,
Whose heads, because out little witted,
Shall with garlands straight be fitted.
Speak who are tossed on Cupid's billows,
And receive the crown of willows,
This way, that way, round about,
Keep your heads from breaking out.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This is excellent, nay nay gentlemen
You must obey the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: He took measure of my head.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: It must be my fate too.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now we beth:

sp.speaker: M. Bo.
sp.l: And if you please to try, I do not think
But this would sit you excellently.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Mine! What does he mean?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I prithee master Lacy try for once,
Nay he, he has some conceit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: For thy sake I'll do any thing, what now?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: You're now a mess of willow gentlemen,
And now my lord I'll presume to bid you welcome,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Is not this the gentleman made you dance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My new acquaintance, where's thy beard?

sp.speaker: M. Bo.
sp.l: I left it at the barbers, it grew rank,
And he has reaped it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Here, take thy toy again.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: It sha'not need.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You tell me wonders lady; is this gentleman
Your husband?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ca. How her husband my lord?

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Yes indeed lady, if you please you may
Call me your kinsman, seven year and misfortune,
I confess, had much disguised me, but I was
And by degrees 〈…〉 her husband.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: After a tedious 〈…〉
Arrived to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: This is rate!

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: My lord and gentlemen,
You're no less welcome than before, m. Lacy droop not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This turn was above all expectation
And full of wonder, I congratulate
Your mutual happiness.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: All of a brotherhood.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: M. Bonavent, a my conscience 'tis he!
Did fortune owe me this?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: A thousand welcomes.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Equal joys to thee, and master Fairfield.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Nay then you but obey the ceremony.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I was not ripe for such a blessing, take her,
And with an honest heart I wish you joys,
Welcome to life again, I see a providence
In this, and I obey it.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: In such good company 'twould never grieve
A man to wear the willow.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: You have but changed
Your host, whose heart proclaims a general welcome.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: He was discovered to me in the park,
Though I concealed it.

sp.speaker: M. B.
sp.l: Every circumstance
Of my absence, after supper we'll discourse of,
I will not doubt your lordship means to honour us.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I'll be your guest, and drink a jovial health
To your new marriage, and the joys of your
expected bride, here after you may do
As much for me, fair lady will you write
Me in your thoughts, if I desire to be
A servant to your virtue, will you not
Frown on me then?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Never in noble ways;
No virgin shall more honour you.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: By thy cure
I am now myself, yet dare call nothing mine,
Till I be perfect blessed in being thine.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
